article.title: Radiation pressure in super star cluster formation

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 demonstrate about the Discrete Diffusion Monte Carlo (DDMC) method in radiation transport?
choices: DDMC is less accurate than the basic Monte Carlo method but faster.
DDMC produces artifacts at the interface with the Implicit Monte Carlo (IMC) region.
DDMC achieves similar accuracy to the basic Monte Carlo method with fewer Monte Carlo particles (MCPs) and a coarser mesh.
DDMC cannot handle coincident jumps in cell size and optical thickness.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the right panel of Figure 2 illustrate about the coupling of radiation to the dense shell in the radiation-pressure-driven shell test?
choices: Radiative force reaches its quasi-steady-state level instantly.
Limited momentum flux due to finite travel time of radiation results in complete momentum coupling at all times.
The agreement between effective radiative force and shell optical depth is poor throughout the simulation.
At early times, the radiative force has not yet reached its quasi-steady-state level because radiation has not yet diffused through the entire thickness of the shell.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 9 suggest about the impact of radiation pressure on the final peak stellar density in the simulated star cluster?
choices: Radiation pressure significantly limits the final peak stellar density.
The peak stellar density is identical in the runs with and without radiation pressure.
Radiation pressure has no impact on the final peak stellar density.
The peak stellar density is lower in the run with radiation pressure, but still reaches values where runaway stellar merging can occur.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 13 depicts the evolution of the Eddington ratio in the simulated star cluster. What does the comparison between the mass-weighted and volume-weighted ratios reveal about the impact of radiation pressure?
choices: Both the mass-weighted and volume-weighted Eddington ratios are consistently super-Eddington.
The mass-weighted Eddington ratio is consistently super-Eddington, while the volume-weighted ratio is sub-Eddington.
Radiation-matter anti-correlation makes the mass-weighted Eddington ratio sub-Eddington, while the volume-weighted ratio stays close to the spherically-symmetric analytical value.
The difference between mass-weighted and volume-weighted Eddington ratios is negligible.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the right panel of Figure 16 regarding the origin of density variations in the simulated star cluster?
choices: Density variations are solely driven by radiation pressure.
Density variations are independent of the presence of radiation, suggesting they are primarily driven by turbulent collapse.
Density variations are only present in the run with radiation pressure.
Density variations are only present in the run without radiation pressure.
